text: it should have been a routine operation
but it turned into a nightmare
experience for Iona havoc and from
Cornwall after a wait of several months
for a hysterectomy the operation was
postponed the day before it was due and
then cancelled again on the day itself
she felt so upset she went straight to
her local radio station in a hospital
gown to talk about her experience
because you can see my name tags on the
operation did eventually take place and
went smoothly but Iona who's
self-employed won't forget the stress
caused by being told of cancellations
with very limited notice every time they
give you a date to go into operation
there's a lot of preparing before you go
in for that day so any cancellation that
you get is obviously a very traumatic
time because of everything you got it
all your plans you made everything
you've dared you mindset everything
official figures shows seven point seven
million operations were carried out in
England last year one percent involved
last-minute cancellations on the
original day for non-medical reasons
patients were guaranteed a new date
within 28 days but a BBC investigation
with responses from nearly half of
hospital trusts uncovered an additional
short notice cancellation problem they
said nearly forty one and a half
thousand were cancelled one to three
days before the shed yield day these
don't show up in any official figures
and there's no 28-day guarantee of a new
date Scotland Wales and Northern Ireland
used different definitions for
last-minute cancelations Hospital Chiefs
in England admit there's a growing
problem but say increasing patient
numbers are putting pressure on wards
and operating theatres in a situation
where we've got so many people needing
planned operations and an increasing
level of emergency admissions then we
have a situation where we often need to
cancel the planned Hospital operation
and isn't that pretty devastating for
the patient's me absolutely devastating
for the patient involvement we don't
underestimate what that means I owner
simply feel she was passed around the
system with no sympathy for her welfare
well I did feel like was a piece of meat
and they could do basically what they
want
they don't understand your emotions that
you need to go with it it's the
emotional side it's a hospital there
should be beds for everybody I've got
problems as much as the next person the
local hospital said it was working hard
to reduce short notice cancellations
Iona's view as it has to be a priority
for hospitals across the country q p.m.
BBC News
